subtitle: [Music]
Thinking Allowed.
Conversations on the leading edge of
knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove. Hello and
welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. We will be
exploring the practical applications of
remote viewing today. With me is one of
the world's foremost remote viewers,
Joseph McMoneagle, the co-author of ESP
Wars: East and West, and the author of
Remote Viewing Secrets, Mind Trek, The
Stargate Chronicles: Memoirs of a Psychic
Spy, and The Ultimate Time Machine.
Welcome, Joe. Glad to be here. You’ve worked on
both pure research projects and
applied projects for remote viewing. What
would you say is the essential
difference there? The difference has to
do with the.. Well, let me backup.
When you do a real-world target, it's
actually better. You get a much better
result than when you do something that's
been concocted in a lab that you want to
study. You would think it would be the
opposite way around, but it's not. By
real world target, I think you mean
something where there's an emotional
necessity. Yes, there's a reason that
we think that happens. It has to do with
intent. Intent drives
everything. You don't even need an
address for the target with intent. We
found that people would
come and say, “I need you to find out
about A.” You can say, “Okay, put that in a
double wrapped opaque envelope,” and that's
what they would do. But eventually they
show up one morning and then say, “Oh my
God, I left it.
I left the opaque envelope laying on my desk.”
Okay, write that down and put it in another
envelope. It works just as well. The
point is whether it's a research project,
pure research or an applied project, you want to be blind. You don't want to have
information about, we're trying to find so and so
or such and such. That's right. You’re
giving up part of
your quality check. For instance, if
you know who you're looking for,
let's say it's a 56-year-old woman, and I
don’t [know] and I go in to do the remote
viewing, my first task is to describe
the person I'm looking for.
I either describe a 56-year-old woman
that has a certain background or I
describe something else, which will be
totally wrong. If you describe
something else then they know to discount
whatever else... Just
discount this because it’s probably not
on. What if someone comes to
you and they say, “We're looking for oil
reserves, or natural gas reserves, or gold,”
then you know already.
Well, you kind of do and you kind of
don't. You can still provide basic
essential information which you do not
understand how it relates to the target,
but they do. So if they're
looking for oil and it's in the southern
area of Alaska, for instance, in the
Denali mountain range. No
one's ever looked for oil there before
but that's where they're going to go to look. You, as a remote viewer, can
probably say this is coming out of a
place that's never been searched before.
It's in an area of a national park.
There are a lot of things you could say about it
that are material to the target.
It says something about what it is
they're doing. If those relationships that
you're relating turn out to be
accurate, that tells you something about
the accuracy of the facts.
I believe the term is
front-loading when we actually have a
little information about the target. Exactly. You do not
ever want to front-load
because what happens is if somebody
tells me what I'm working on then
it makes it very difficult
for me to divide out or divine which is my
actual psychic information, or remote
viewing information, and what am I just thinking of that I can remember. The
intellect is going to try to jump all over it. Get in the way,
take over, exactly. This
is a task. Remote viewing is a task
where the ego has absolutely got to be
beaten down and pushed aside.
If you can't control the ego you're not
going to do any remote viewing that is going to
be effective. Which is why I suppose a
lot of people who are very brilliant
scientists may not be good remote
viewers because they have an investment
in being very smart people. Exactly. They
have a vested interest in how
it comes out. So, yeah, intent is
extremely important. Attention to details
is very important and expectation for
outcome. If you don't have the right
expectation for what's going to happen,
even though you may not know what it is,
if you don't have the right sort of
energy around it, it just plain isn't
going to happen. By the energy you
mean, I think, a feeling of confidence.
Exactly. It's out of that confidence
that the information comes.
It's not going to come out of what you
shut down and don't pay any attention to.
It's very interesting because
parapsychological data, by and large, is
statistical and it's sort of
iffy. The statisticians have been
arguing over it for decades.
And yet, many people who do
real life work say, “It works all
the time. I get excellent results.” You
seem to be confirming that.
When there's a real human need the
results are better. Especially if the
need involves life or death.
That is the essential ingredient.
Let's talk about, for example,
criminology in police work. I am under
the impression that when a big case hits
the news, that police departments, the FBI,
are inundated by people who think that
they have psychic insights. Significant problem.
That happens all the time.
I'll tell you quite frankly, if you are
an exceptional remote viewer, no matter how
good you are, if you can't sell your
product you're going to be in a lot of
trouble. You can take that to the
local sheriff or the local gendarme
or whoever you're taking it to for police
action. They
will take one look at it, put it with all
the other psychic stuff, and throw it in the
dump. The reason why is they don't know how to evaluate it. They don't know
what they're looking at. It doesn't make
any sense to them. They don’t know how to
analyze it in a way that makes it of value. They might not at all be educated
about the decades of work that you've
put into it and other government
programs have put into it. Exactly right.
It may be totally wrong
because that has happened too.
That reminds me, it's sort of an
application. General Dozier, who is the
UN General for Italy, a
one-star General, was kidnapped by
the Red Brigade. The Red
Brigades are a particularly nasty group.
They usually kill their victims
eventually. That was back in the 1970s.
Yes, the late 70’s, in fact.
General Dozier, we did a really good
session on him. There were two of us
and we were able to define the fact
that he was in Ravenna, Italy. I think it
was Ravenna. He was on the
end of a dead-end road with a circle
around a fountain. It was in a four-
section apartment building. He
was being held on the third or fourth
entry way. He was in a
ground-level apartment. He had a
mask over his face, headset taped to his
ears, and he was chained to a hot water
system mounted on the wall. Radiator.
Inside a tent. I guess that was supposed to confuse
him. Lots of information. Many details. Yes.
They were playing rock music in his
ears. We are getting tons of really
important data. If you look at a husband
worried about his daughters and his wife,
we got great data.
Really good stuff. When you look at
finding him, it was a lot more cloudy
and it was very difficult. We sent our data to
Italy. Italy would not use it because
they had used psychic information from
some of the locals. Translate that to
mean 1,500 papers had hit the place in
no time at all. The first raid they
made was on a house of ill repute
that had one of their senators in it. His
wife was not as understanding as
he might have wanted her to be. A second person
was outed, basically, by this information
because they went to the wrong place again.
So, they notified us basically that they
weren't going to use the information. It
turns out that they were able to capture
the brother of one
of the Red Brigade's members. That
brother was able to confirm the stuff in
our report. As a result, or prior to that, maybe
from other things—we don't know, because the Italian police won't say—they were able
to rescue General Dozier. In
fact, he was in a tent in an apartment,
chained to a radiator, with rock music
blaring away in his ears. We thought,
this is the perfect person. We can bring
him back. He's probably got a clearance.
We can read him on
and have him look at his own file and
tell us what in there is accurate and what
isn't. He read that file probably
four times. His conclusion was—
it surprised everybody—that
you need to start a school where you
could teach people how to think to aid
in their own rescue.
That was his recommendation. He said, “All
the stuff in here about what I was
thinking, not only is it accurate, it's in order.”
It was just amazing to him. He was
blown away. In other words, even though the
Stargate program that you were involved
in has been discontinued, General Dozier
who eventually was rescued,
although not necessarily based on your
information, confirmed that your
information was so good that it could be
taken to the next level. Exactly.
He said let's start something here. Let’s
teach people who go overseas, who might
be at risk, how to think. How to signal,
maybe, too. Exactly.
Give messages. I
thought it was a brilliant idea. It
went the way of the
aardvarks. Nobody cared about it.
We've had a number of things like that.
The General Dozier case, to me, is
clear-cut in this sense, that it's
an ethically good thing to do, to rescue
somebody who's been kidnapped. Absolutely.
There were a number of other kidnappings.
Some we were able to effect a rescue
in, some we were not. It was a Colonel
Higgins—he was a friend,
I knew him personally—he was kidnapped
by Hezbollah in Lebanon. He was the
UN representative for America in
Lebanon. I and a number of other people
had like drawings of where he was being
held. It was sufficient information to
match it to an actual location. They
didn't have confirming information from
another intelligence source. So they were
refused permission to go in and raid
the building. We found out six months later
it was all dead accurate. They could
have saved his life had they gone in.
People get angry about that. I don't
because you have got to define
the rules up front. You can't wait
till it's over and make the rules up.
It's got to be in the front end
because otherwise that's how more people
than one person wind up dead. It seems
to me that cases of this sort can be
pretty clear-cut from an ethical point
of view, but many potential practical
applications are not. People who
attempt to use remote viewing for
speculating in the stock market. I think
you pointed out to me earlier that you don't
like that because for every winner
there's a loser.
Even worse than that, Jeff. For
every winner there's probably a thousand
losers, because you don’t start calling
yourself a winner until you put a
couple grand in your pocket.
Somebody had to lose that. It's
the housewife. It’s the
inveterate gambler who comes in there and
just keeps pumping the money into the
machines. I know it's stacked for the house, so I don't go near it.
Or locating oil and minerals, which I
believe you have done. Also, there's the
question of environmental degradation.
Yeah, that's true.
The only job that I've ever taken with
regard to minerals was with a specific company, and I can't tell you
where that was. They gave me an
actual written document that said,
“This is how we will do it and this is
how we will return it to the people.”
They did that, exactly what they
said in writing that they gave to me. One
of my requirements when I do work for a
corporation or business—
usually it’s oriented at profit—my one
requirement is they're going to have to
tithe 10% to any charity of their choice.
If I find out they're not, I walk.
I'll tell you what, in six months,
without exception, I've had CEOs and CFOs
come up to me and say, “If I knew giving
away money was going to make me this much
money I would have done it 20 years ago.”
I mean, it's only the right thing to do.
Are you suggesting that this idea of
having your clients tithe some of their
profits actually makes the
remote viewing more effective? Absolutely,
because what it does is it gets
everybody on board in a positive way, not
in a negative way.
Everybody goes, “Well, that's a good thing.”
It's like building this patchwork around
the actual target. Everything
that creates that patchwork around the
target is a good thing. There's a reason
why it needs to succeed. If everybody is
aware of those things, it's a fait
accompli. With regard to
practical applications, I'm under the
impression that people specialize. For
example, I don't think everybody has the
constitution to apprehend a murderer.
Right, exactly. But there are times
for that too. I'm reminded of a case of a
woman by the name of Angela Ford. She was
one of our best… Is one of our best
viewers at the sciences
lab, and prior to that at SAIC, Science
Applications International Corporation.
She was asked to try to describe an area
in which a DEA agent had stolen 2
million dollars and then vanished. She
was asked to describe where he was.
She gave that description. She
said, “He's way up north.” Now, this is
the middle of the winter. He's way
up north. He's somewhere up like
northern Indiana or maybe northern
Dakota. She's not quite certain. But
she said, “He's in a Motel 6, which is
right next to an Exxon
gas station. Behind the motel is a
graveyard for American Indians.”
Pretty specific.
So what they did, the FBI and DEA, they
took the guy’s picture and the
warrant and they faxed it to all of the park
superintendents up in that area. There was
a park superintendent going home one night who
stopped at a gas station to get gas, and saw
the guy walking into the motel. He
saw the flier, notified the DEA and they
arrested the guy, with the money.
He was hiding up there in the winter
because he knew that no one would ever
logically look there. They probably
figured he’d go south. They
were looking in the Bahamas, for God’s sake.
The French Islands. They were looking everywhere down in the
south. Nowhere in the north. I'm
sorry, but that's not a fluke. That's a
really good remote viewing passed to
the appropriate person who can put more
intelligence with it and know where the
guy is. It was instrumental in leading to an
arrest.
Absolutely, and we had the
statements by then to prove it. If one
were to look at all of the potential
applications, you've got military
intelligence, you’ve got law enforcement,
cases in oil and minerals, financial
forecasting, we’ve talked about
archaeological research, we've even
talked about the possibility of using
remote viewing to develop new technologies.
Which of these applications do you think
offers the most promise? All of the above is
what I want to say.
The best promise, I think, has to do with
the open-mindedness of the normal
American businessman. Any
businessman can actually set this up himself and
use it for the benefit of his business
if you just read a few lines about the
protocol and tried to apply it in a way
that actually isolated intent.
I think that would work fine.
You mean business people can become their own
remote viewers. Exactly, exactly right.
Maybe not their own since they're
setting up the target,
but they could ask other people who are
complete strangers to the issue to give them the information. It is a
team that's really required. In fact, I
think you and I had a discussion earlier
about the dangers of having a remote
viewer judge their own response. Oh my God, yes.
There are people out there who are making that recommendation as we sit
here. They're saying, “... And then you
judge yourself.” I'm sorry, but
the person who does the viewing has a
certain prejudice based on what they've
drawn or what they’ve said.
It's inevitable. They may not be thinking
about it right then but if they look at
something to judge it against, they're
going to see what they've written or drawn,
it's in that picture, and then in the
next picture. That's going to confuse
them because, now, which one is it really?
They’re going to wind up
guessing. It is very destructive to the
whole process. Judging is an art in
and of itself. Yes, and the judge has to
be blind. The judge is blind, the analyst
is blind, the remote viewer is blind, and the
monitor is blind. How important is feedback?
Actually, in the beginning we thought it
was extremely important because we
weren't sure if it wasn't the remote
viewer themselves sending the
information to themselves in the past.
Which is another reason why you
never want to show the remote viewer
something that's varied from the
actual target. In other words, in many
research studies you're going to compare
the transcript provided by a viewer
against maybe a pool of
potential targets. Right, and only one of them's
correct. It's essentially
the same thing when you ask somebody to
judge themselves. They are now
seeing two out of two
possibilities. How are they going to
ever figure out what the psychic information was?
In other words, they are getting feedback
on an inaccurate target plus an accurate target.
What if they get no feedback at all?
Indications from research over decades
say it does not matter. All they
need to know is it's important enough
for them to work on. There is
this model that people learn
through feedback. I think what
you're saying is that model may not be
applicable. Exactly,
I guess a better model would be… Let's just
go back over it and see what tasted
better to you than not. In other words,
they're going to have to develop the
methodology by which they are
going to do their remote viewing.
Way early in the Stargate program they
were asking me to do all kinds of
things. Go into an all gray room,
lie down on the couch, get your head
right. Just different things.
Part of it became kind of ridiculous.
They put in sound proofing and sealed the
windows off because the birds
outside were too loud. Then you would have
squirrels running on the roof, so they would
have to put these bands up to keep the
squirrels from jumping on the roof.
It just became another thing, another thing.
They actually had a list, a checklist, it
probably had 28 items. Check the things
that got in your way. I
carried that in to my boss, the Colonel,
and I said, “This is a list for failure.
Look, I have a reason right here. I don't
feel very good this morning. Got
another reason. Look, this is an excuse
sheet for failure. I don't want to see it
again.” I crumpled it up and threw it into his
wastebasket. Checklists are very popular.
Because they are easy to judge.
I threw it in his trash can and
said, “In fact, I'm going to do
some of my viewing sitting right at my desk,
phones ringing, people yelling at each
other, asking me if I want coffee,
whatever. I'm going to do it at my desk
because if I can't do it there, I can't
do it anywhere of value for the Army.
See, I was a soldier. If you
can't do remote viewing in the field
under any circumstances you're wasting
your time. The Russians, in fact, their
best remote viewer got one of their
highest peacetime, no... I think it was a
combat ribbon. One of their highest combat
ribbons. Their best remote viewer was a
woman. She did all remote viewing from a
mainline battle tank, on site in Chechnya,
during the Chechnian wars.
I asked her, “What are you, crazy?
You don't have to be there, you can be in
Moscow in a beautiful, luxurious
apartment. What are you doing in a
tank in the middle of war?” She said,
“They needed that to believe what I was
giving them.” I find that really
interesting. Likewise,
the operations officer who gave me my
assignments, “Give us a
description from a perspective of 3000
ft at a 45 degree oblique,”
whatever this target is. That kind of thing. That’s not a
hint about the target. That’s how
I am supposed to do it. It’s an
instruction. He came to me…
This wasn’t too long ago, three weeks ago. He
said, “You know what was really hard with
you?” I said, “What?” He said, “Sometimes I
was up all night trying to look for
exactly the right words to give you as
direction so that it would elicit a
response in the right way that might
give us an answer.”
I said, “Well, that’s pretty funny
because I really didn’t care what you
said to me.” (laughter) He said, “What?” I said, “No.
Understand, I am used to dealing with
agents from the CIA, the FBI, places like that.
They don’t even know what remote viewing
is. They show up. And they want to know,
how do I write this out? What do I do?”
I always say, “Just let me
take care of that.” The last thing I say in my mind when I start remote viewing
is, “Let me give them whatever is going to
make them happy." The key there is that remote viewing seems
goal-oriented. If you have the goal in
mind all of these other instructions are
irrelevant. Absolutely. The highest
goal of all, if you want to call it a
goal, I hesitate to call it a goal.
I call it something else. But it was a
nuclear weapon, nuclear material.
In all the time I’ve been doing remote
viewing from beginning to end,
nearing 40 years, I have never missed a
nuclear target, ever.
That is very interesting. Yes, isn’t
it? That goes to entropy, at least informational
entropy. Which is another topic entirely.
Fortunately, I hope to discuss it with
your colleague Ed May, who’s the specialist
on the gradient of entropy with
regard to remote viewing targets.
Joe McMoneagle, thank you so much for
sharing this time with me. You're very
welcome, Jeff. I am glad to be here. I am
glad you are. And thank you for being with us.
[Music]
